image.altText: Josh Hazlewood holds his arms in the in celebration while a despairing Ben Stokes keels over his bat

items.synopsis: Australia wins the second Test at Lord's, despite a masterful innings from England captain Ben Stokes taking his side within touching distance of another Ashes miracle.

title.children: Australia survives Stokes onslaught to win at Lord's as crowd accuses Aussies of cheating

image.altText: A screenshot showing Australian cricketers walking through the Lord's Long Room, with Usman Khawaja talking to a member.

items.synopsis: The final day of the second Ashes Test at Lord's is filled with drama thanks to Ben Stokes, a rarely seen stumping of Jonny Bairstow and "disappointing" abuse from the Lord's members. Here are five big moments from a dramatic finale.

title.children: Five quick hits — Bairstow's stumping against the 'spirit of the game' and Khawaja confronts Lord's members

image.altText: Real estate agent puts up a sold sticker after this Mosman apartment sold at auction.

items.synopsis: Sydney, and particularly the most expensive areas within it, is leading a national house price rebound. But can it survive further interest rate rises and a possible recession?

title.children: The 'real danger' confronting property markets as house prices continue to rebound

image.altText: Laura wearing a grey jumper, holding her four-year-old daughter in her arms.

items.synopsis: The federal government is spending $5.4 billion to reduce the childcare costs of about 1.2 million families. But with high inflation and quirks in the system, there's concerns some parents won't see much savings.

title.children: 'A minefield': Why the childcare subsidy policy means some parents will get more than others

image.altText: A wide shot of players walking off a field.

items.synopsis: As Australia claims fans tried to trip players walking off the Lord's field for lunch, the MCC confirms it has suspended three members for their behaviour during the final day of the second Test.

title.children: Australia claims fans at Lord's attempted to trip players coming off the field, as the MCC confirms suspension of three members

image.altText: Several retail fireworks placed in front of a cardboard box.

items.synopsis: Authorities say two men were taken to hospital after the incident, which unfolded at an address in the Darwin rural area.

title.children: Darwin man loses lower arm in fireworks-related incident as firefighters respond to nearly 100 blazes

image.altText: a close-up of a person holding several pages of a household power bill in their hands

items.synopsis: In addition to the federal Energy Bill Relief Fund, many Australian states offer power rebates to certain households and small business.

title.children: Struggling with rising power costs? Here's a state-by-state breakdown of what government rebates and concessions are available

image.altText: A burnt out white car on the back of a large tow truck on a French street.

items.synopsis: The grandmother of the teenager shot dead by police during a traffic stop in a Paris suburb says she wants the rioters to stop, as the home of a Paris suburb mayor is ram-raided and set alight.

title.children: Wife of French mayor undergoes surgery after fleeing from home rammed by car and set alight

image.altText: A woman sitting in a house.

items.synopsis: Apartments and townhouses make up nearly 30 per cent of homes in Australia, and some owners are feeling blindsided by strata fees which have climbed by up to 45 per cent in the past year.

title.children: 'I'll probably have to sell the place': Andrea felt blindsided when her strata fees went up by 45 per cent

image.altText: A composite of three people in front of a motorway and street signs.

items.synopsis: Millions of Australians face the daily frustration of delayed commutes, particularly on busy motorways. But as governments spend billions continually upgrading roads, experts say that might not be the best solution.

title.children: Meet the motorists tackling one of Australia's busiest commutes

image.altText: Ben Stokes and Pat Cummins are not looking at each other as they stand side by side

items.synopsis: Australia held its nerve to secure victory at Lord's and a 2-0 series lead, but that doesn't tell half the story of a day when the Ashes exploded into firey and controversial life.

title.children: Stokes stuns, Australia prevails but the Ashes just erupted into contentious, furious life

image.altText: The black stone exterior of the RBA building in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Markets are divided about whether the Reserve Bank of Australia will increase interest rates at its meeting tomorrow, while Australian house prices continue to rebound. Follow live.

title.children: Markets weigh possible interest rate rise ahead of RBA meeting, property prices surge

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A former Reserve Bank board member says the RBA should pause its current interest rate hiking cycle at its meeting tomorrow, or else it risks overshooting its efforts to control inflation. Three of the big four banks are now predicting another interest rate rise when the RBA board meets tomorrow, expecting a 0.25 percentage point increase to 4.35%. The Commonwealth Bank is the only bank that isn't expecting the RBA to hike rates again tomorrow. Former RBA board member Warwick McKibbin told RN Breakfast the market needs time to respond to the rate hikes. "Suppose we are getting a supply shock which is pushing inflation down and we keep raising interest rates we could quite easily overshoot on the downside because the response to the interest rate policies is about 6-12 months so you could make things a lot worse next year," he said. Mr McKibbin also says he wants to see the federal government to do more to ease inflation, in particular policies to boost productivity. "I think what the government said before the election, I fully agreed with their productivity agenda, bringing women into the labour force etc, helping with childcare but what's been delivered so far has been very disappointing," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former RBA board member says central bank should pause rate rises

children.content: A former Reserve Bank board member says the
RBA should pause its current interest rate hiking cycle
at its meeting tomorrow, or else it risks overshooting its efforts to control inflation.
Three of the big four banks are now predicting another interest rate rise when the RBA board meets tomorrow, expecting a 0.25 percentage point increase to 4.35%.
The Commonwealth Bank is the only bank that isn't expecting the RBA to hike rates again tomorrow.
Former RBA board member
Warwick McKibbin
told RN Breakfast the market needs time to respond to the rate hikes.

"Suppose we are getting a supply shock which is pushing inflation down and we keep raising interest rates we could quite easily overshoot on the downside because the response to the interest rate policies is about 6-12 months so you could make things a lot worse next year," he said.
Mr McKibbin also says he wants to see the federal government to do more to ease inflation, in particular policies to boost productivity.

"I think what the government said before the election, I fully agreed with their productivity agenda, bringing women into the labour force etc, helping with childcare but what's been delivered so far has been very disappointing," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Greens Senator Barbara Pocock has confirmed she's referred the beleaguered consulting firm PwC's tax leaks scandal to the new National Anti-Corruption Commission. The NACC first became operational on Saturday, July 1, and was a key election commitment of the Albanese government. Speaking to RN Breakfast's Patricia Karvelas, Senator Pocock said she submitted the case to the NACC on Saturday: "What I've done is listen to a lot of Australians who … want corruption and poor behaviour in the private sector and in relationship to government called out," she said. "So ... submitting this request to NACC to investigate corruption within PwC I think is a very straightforward thing that hopefully will be top of the list for the NACC when it turns to its agenda hopefully this week." You can see part of her submission below: If you want to hear the full chat, you can listen back below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC referred to new National Anti-Corruption Commission

featuredLink.title: Greens refer PwC to NACC - ABC Radio National

children.content: Greens Senator Barbara Pocock
has confirmed she's referred the beleaguered consulting firm
PwC's tax leaks scandal
to the new
National Anti-Corruption Commission
The NACC first became operational on Saturday, July 1, and was a key election commitment of the Albanese government.
Speaking to
RN Breakfast's Patricia Karvelas
, Senator Pocock said she submitted the case to the NACC on Saturday:
"What I've done is listen to a lot of Australians who … want corruption and poor behaviour in the private sector and in relationship to government called out," she said.

"So ... submitting this request to NACC to investigate corruption within PwC I think is a very straightforward thing that hopefully will be top of the list for the NACC when it turns to its agenda hopefully this week."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning and welcome to July! It's Monday, July 3 and you're reading the ABC's business and finance blog. Let's get the obvious out of the way first — a new month means a new interest rate decision is squarely front of mind for the Reserve Bank of Australia. At the moment, it's looking like it could go either way, but earlier this morning markets were pricing the likelihood of a rate rise at 69%. But it's not just markets that think a hike might be on the cards — NAB and Westpac are both expecting a 0.25 percentage point rise tomorrow, which would take the cash rate to 4.35%. That's despite inflation coming down. Here's Westpac said in its thinking, which it sent out on Friday: "With core inflation holding above 6% ; the unemployment rate holding nearly 1 [percentage point] below the NAIRU (RBA’s estimate) and the cash rate only around 1 [percentage point] into contractionary territory (we see neutral around 3%) the cash rate will need to go higher ." Another factor that the RBA will be taking into consideration? Property prices. CoreLogic data shows they're continuing to rebound, with home prices rising by 1.1% across the nation last month, on average. Sydney is leading the gains with a 1.7% rise, while Brisbane rose 1.3%, and Peth and Adelaide were up 0.9% each. The only place where property prices fell? Hobart — they were down 0.3%. Meanwhile on the market front, we can expect the ASX to open higher, off the SPI futures trending higher. All that said, it's the first (business) day of the new financial year, so let's see what's in store.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX to open higher as RBA's latest interest rate decision looms
